I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) cluster will support the preparation 
of economic diagnostic studies to assist developing member countries (DMCs) enhance national 
development plans and strategies for achieving sustained and inclusive growth.1 The studies will 
utilize the latest tools, methodologies, and data to help identify macroeconomic, sector, and 
thematic constraints to growth and inclusion; and recommend policy actions for relaxing these 
constraints, paying careful attention to the costs and benefits of alternative interventions. The TA 
will also support capacity building for DMCs to undertake an economic diagnostic approach 
toward development planning. 
 
2.  The TA cluster is included in the Management-approved 2021 Economic Research and 
Regional Cooperation Department (ERCD) work program.2 
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
3.  Many  countries  in  Asia  and  the  Pacific  have  made  significant  strides  in  achieving 
sustained economic growth and poverty reduction in the last 5 decades. However, a lot still needs 
to be done to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), especially when these 
achievements are tested by external shocks such as the ongoing coronavirus disease pandemic 
or the 2007–2008 global financial crisis, which led to large contractions in most economies. 
Beyond the immediate human and economic impacts of the coronavirus disease crisis, the 
pandemic has also exacerbated the development challenges that countries in the region had 
already  faced  and  has  further  highlighted  the  importance  of  well-functioning  markets  and 
evidence-based  policy  interventions  to  recover  from  shocks.  The  crisis  also  provides  an 
opportunity for economic policy to correct market failures and regulatory distortions that may 
otherwise have been difficult to unwind.3 Thus the need to carry out diagnostic studies has 
become even more important, as the studies can assist DMC governments in addressing the 
most pressing challenges faced by their economies for achieving inclusive and sustainable 
growth.   
 
4.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) introduced diagnostic studies in 2007 under the 
Strengthening Country Diagnosis and Analysis of Binding Development Constraints in Selected 
Developing Member Countries TA project, with the objective of improving DMCs’ capacity to plan, 
implement, and account for the outcomes of the policies, program, and projects they implement.4 
Under this 2007 TA project and succeeding TA projects, ADB was able to collaborate with DMC

governments and various development partners in conducting country diagnostic studies.5 These 
studies utilized diagnostic approaches and quantitative methodologies to identify constraints to 
inclusive and sustainable growth at the macroeconomic, sector, and thematic levels. 
 
5.  Whereas some upper middle-income countries in the region may have the expertise, most 
DMCs lack the analytical and planning capacity to undertake high-quality diagnostic analysis. The 
conduct of diagnostic studies will help low- and middle-income DMCs identify the most pressing 
challenges in the medium and long term and focus their limited resources toward addressing the 
most critical constraints at the macroeconomic, sector, and thematic levels. Under Strategy 2030, 
ADB is enhancing its role as a knowledge provider by developing knowledge that is tailored to 
local contexts and helping replicate lessons and good practices across the region to help achieve 
the Sustainable Development Goal.6 The diagnostic studies will undertake analyses in priority 
areas that can deliver useful inputs to prepare national development plans; sector and thematic 
development strategies; and ADB interventions, including country partnership strategy (CPS) 
documents. With the overarching objective of identifying constraints to high growth that is 
inclusive and sustainable, the diagnostic studies will directly or indirectly be aligned with all the 
operational priorities (OP) of Strategy 2030. 
  
6.  To ensure that these diagnostic studies cater to the needs of the DMCs, the studies will 
follow Strategy 2030 principles on adopting a country-focused approach. Individual studies will 
use a differentiated approach since DMCs face different challenges given their various stages of 
development.7  The diagnostic studies will also help identify and quantify, where possible, the 
potential costs and benefits of tailored recommended policy and other related actions. The 
diagnostic studies will be aligned with the objectives of the Knowledge Management Action Plan, 
2021–2025,8 which  aims  to  improve  country  knowledge  programming  efforts  and  better 
understand DMCs’ knowledge needs. 
   
7.  While the frameworks utilized for the conduct of earlier diagnostic studies remain relevant, 
the availability of newer methodologies and the use of big data can help improve the reliability of 
study findings.9  Likewise, DMCs prefer real-time and flexible support through studies that can be 
completed quickly. This can be accomplished by shifting the focus of the studies from the 
publication of one large, edited volume covering a range of topics to shorter and more focused 
reports. Finally, a greater focus on sector and thematic issues can allow for more in-depth analysis 
and, if undertaken for several countries, can also enable comparative analyses across countries 
to highlight lessons and best practices.

III.  JUSTIFICATION FOR CLUSTER MODALITY 
 
8.  The TA cluster and its subprojects are strategically linked to one common overall objective 
and adopting a cluster modality enables ADB to cater to the demand for diagnostic studies in a 
more systematic way and over a longer period without tying down TA resource requirements 
entirely at the onset. Moreover, experience with the first TA cluster on the conduct of diagnostic 
studies suggests that adopting a cluster modality allows the TA to be more responsive to the 
needs and timing of DMCs’ planning cycles and ADB’s CPSs given the flexibility in the design 
and its implementation arrangements. Finally, processing the TA as a cluster reduces the 
resources that would otherwise be associated with processing individual subprojects as stand-
alone TA interventions. 
 
IV.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.  Impact, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
9.  The TA cluster is aligned with the following impact: critical constraints to ADB’s DMCs’ 
inclusive and sustainable economic growth addressed. The TA cluster will have the following 
outcome: diagnostic approaches and methodologies in the development planning processes of 
DMCs adopted and/or improved.10  
      
10.  The TA cluster will comprise three subprojects, each of which will provide technical and 
analytical as well as capacity building support to DMCs to enable the identification of policy actions 
and investments that can help address development constraints. The three subprojects under the 
TA cluster will comprise two main outputs: (i) diagnostic studies conducted and/or published, and 
(ii)  the  capacity  of  developing  member  country  officials  to  employ  diagnostic  approaches, 
methodologies and tools to conduct economic and policy analysis developed and enhanced. The 
design of subsequent subprojects will benefit from lessons learned from the implementation of 
subproject 1. 
 
11.  Output 1: Diagnostic studies conducted and/or published. This will support the 
conduct of 6–8 studies per subproject across three different categories of diagnostics. The study 
categories are described as follows: 
 (i)       Diagnostic study on the growth and inclusion performance of developing member 
countries. Two types of studies are envisaged. The first is a narrative style diagnostic 
report of about 30 pages that will provide a broad overview of the economic performance 
of a selected DMC including the policy drivers of the growth and inclusion experience, and 
the types of interventions that are most promising for promoting high, sustained, and 
inclusive. The study will rely mainly on existing literature and readily available descriptive 
statistics.11 The second, which is more technical in nature, will rely more on original 
quantitative analysis and delve deeper into selected aspects of the growth process. The 
first  type  will  feed  directly  into  the  inclusive  sustainable  growth  assessment  linked 
document of the DMC’s CPS, while the second type will be carried out upon request by 
the CPS team, with its specific contents decided based on findings of the first study and/or 
discussions with ADB resident missions and regional departments in line with the recent

(ii)      Diagnostic study on the country’s critical constraints. The report will be like earlier 
country diagnostic studies undertaken, as it will identify constraints to growth and inclusion 
based on an assessment of macroeconomic, sector, and thematic issues. Such studies, 
which take at least a year to produce, will be undertaken in case of strong demand by a 
DMC or regional department. 
 (iii)    Diagnostic study on a sector or thematic area. These reports will be single or multi-
country studies, with the latter allowing comparative policy analysis. These studies are not 
limited by theme or sector, but priority will be given to those aligned with ADB’s Strategy 
2030 priorities.13 New and emerging topics such as technological and digital change will 
also be considered in a forward-looking manner. The topics will be determined by ADB’s 
Economic Analysis and Operational Support Division (EREA) considering inputs and 
suggestions from sector and thematic groups and regional departments. 
 
12.  The publications will be widely disseminated in collaboration with ADB’s Department of 
Communications  and  participating  regional  department  or  resident  missions.  In-country  or 
regional launches will be organized to disseminate the studies. Dissemination events will include 
presentations of study findings and analytical discussions of the study recommendations in 
partnership with academic institutions, think tanks, and/or development partners. The studies will 
be disseminated mainly as electronic files on the ADB website.14  
 
13.   Output  2:  The  capacity  of  developing  member  country  officials  to  employ 
diagnostic approaches, methodologies and tools to conduct economic and policy analysis 
developed and enhanced. The output will include training workshops to help create awareness 
and improve the capacity of DMC officials and think tanks involved in the preparation of national, 
regional, sector, and thematic development plans and policies.15 It will also produce knowledge 
products on the application of the analytical tools that can be used to undertake policy analysis, 
including relevant regional perspectives. Adopting a demonstration approach can help build the 
capacity of DMC planning agencies in integrating economic diagnostic methodologies in their own 
planning activities, including with regard to their participation in subregional programs.16 
 
B.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA cluster is estimated to cost $5,000,000, of which (i) $2,500,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF 7) and (ii) $2,500,000 will 
be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The  three  subprojects  under  the  cluster  will  have  the  following  allocation:  subproject  1: 
$2,000,000, subproject 2: $1,500,000, and subproject 3: $1,500,000 (Appendix 2). Detailed cost

C.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  ADB will administer the TA cluster. EREA will directly handle TA cluster administration 
and supervision, management of consultants, procurement, and accomplishment of outputs. 
Adopting the One ADB approach in knowledge solutions, EREA will collaborate with regional 
departments (including resident missions), other knowledge departments, and relevant sector and 
thematic groups for the activities under each subproject. Each TA subproject proposal will be 
submitted for approval to the ERCD chief economist and director general, following the business 
process for knowledge and support TA cluster processing.17 Subproject activities will start only 
  
after approval of each TA subproject proposal. Implementation arrangements are summarized in 
Table 1.18 
 
16.  EREA will adopt multiple approaches in the identification of studies under output 1, 
including the following: 
(i)  EREA will issue a call for proposals to regional departments and respective resident 
missions, and sector and thematic groups. The proposed topics will be selected or 
prioritized based on ERCD’s capacity and expertise, sector or thematic priorities, and 
relevant country knowledge plans. 
(ii)  EREA will tap the Regional Economic Outlook Task Force, which comprises ERCD 
and regional department staff responsible for analysis of DMC economic prospects, to 
help identify issues especially relevant to medium-term prospects for economic growth 
and diversification and/or the growth assessments associated with CPS preparation. 
(iii)  EREA will discuss with the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
and regional departments to provide support for selected studies in the country 
knowledge plans of DMCs that match with subproject sector or thematic priorities. 
(iv)  EREA will accommodate direct requests from DMCs for any follow-up or new study 
following similar diagnostic studies already conducted. 
(v)  EREA will partner with international financial and research institutions, including the 
ADB Institute, on topics that are of common interest and relevant to ADB DMCs.

18.  Consulting services. The TA cluster will require the services of a mix of individual 
consultants and firms. Requisite fields of expertise and person-months of consulting services in 
the Terms of Reference for Consultants linked document are indicative, and will be finalized upon 
further assessment of the resource needs and availability of qualified consultants.19 Firms may 
be recruited especially if study requires (i) unique expertise; (ii) a team of experts that need to 
collaborate to prepare the study; and (iii) need to access proprietary data platforms and/or conduct 
of sophisticated modelling techniques. The firm/s will be selected through consultant qualification 
selection or direct contracting method. Individual consultants will also be recruited to prepare 
background papers, diagnostic analyses, and chapter/s of the study report/s on topic/s or areas 
identified.  Aside  from  economists,  sector  specialists,  econometrics  specialists  or modelers, 
individual experts to provide economic advisory and economic editing and communications and 
publications related expertise will be engaged. National consultants and research assistants will 
likewise be engaged to provide technical support for data gathering and analysis. National 
consultants will also be needed for the desktop publishing and graphic design of the publication. 
Resource persons will be engaged to provide advice on study scope, undertake review and 
provide comments on the draft reports. Contracts for consulting services will consist of output-
based (lump-sum), time-based or framework contracts, as appropriate, and the consultants and 
resource persons will be recruited based on requisite experience and qualifications. Inasmuch as 
the subprojects will cover a wide range of topics, highly qualified consultants with relevant 
expertise will most likely be associated with specialized firms, research institutions, think tanks,

facilitate the publication process. All consultants will be engaged in accordance with the ADB

19.  Knowledge  partnerships.  EREA  will  seek  to  collaborate  with  reputable  centers  of 
excellence, and these may be engaged through knowledge partnership agreements (KPAs). 
Specific entities will be identified during TA cluster implementation. A nomination proposal will be 
prepared for proposed knowledge partners, and the corresponding KPA will be finalized prior to 
approval of each TA subproject. Where knowledge partners are identified after TA subproject 
approval, EREA will prepare a minor change in implementation arrangements following the Staff 
Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge Partnerships under Technical Assistance 
Operations.20 
 
20.  ADB’s procurement. The TA studies require both macro and micro data. The data sets 
will be procured from government agencies, private data providers, and research institutes. 
Equipment  (e.g.,  laptop  computers,  handheld  devices,  sensors,  and  other  infrastructure 
monitoring equipment) and software may also be procured for the TA where needed.21 Where 
applicable, the TA project team will coordinate with ADB’s Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial 
Management Department and its Office of the General Counsel before purchasing data sets and 
signing data use agreements with DMC statistical agencies and third-party database providers. 
The TA team will also consult ADB’s Information Technology Department and its Corporate 
Services  Department  in  relation  to  the  purchase  of  information  communication  technology 
hardware and software. Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and the associated staff instructions. Upon TA completion, any procured 
equipment  will  be  disposed  of  in  compliance  with  Administering  Grant-Financed  Technical 
Assistance Projects in the Project Administration Instructions.22  
 
21.  Social media and websites. Knowledge product dissemination will be conducted through 
the uploading of TA outputs onto ADB websites and social media, such as Twitter and blogs. This 
will  be  coordinated  closely  with  the  Department  of  Communications  and  the  Information 
Technology Department.

Appendix 2  11   
SUBPROJECT DESCRIPTIONS 
 
Subproject 1  Economic Diagnostic Studies in Asia and the Pacific  
Indicative outputs and activities  Subproject 1 of the TA cluster will deal with the issues and 
challenges faced by ADB DMCs, especially those identified in 
Strategy 2030.a Subproject 1 involves two main outputs: (i) 
diagnostic studies conducted and or published, and (ii) the 
capacity of DMC officials to employ diagnostic approaches, 
methodologies and tools to conduct economic and policy 
analysis developed and enhanced.  
 
Under output 1, 6–8 diagnostic studies will be produced and or 
published. The first category is a report on the growth and 
inclusion performance of DMCs, where two types of studies are 
envisaged. Under the first, the TA will support preparation of a 
short narrative diagnostic that can provide a broad overview of 
the economic performance of a selected DMC, discussing its 
experience in achieving inclusive growth objective and the policy 
drivers that may have contributed to this. The second under this 
category is a more technical report that will use quantitative 
analysis to delve deeper into selected aspects of the growth 
process. 
 
The second category of study is a diagnostic report on the 
country’s critical constraints, which will be similar to earlier 
country diagnostic studies undertaken wherein the study will 
identify constraints to growth and inclusion based on an 
assessment of macroeconomic, sector, and thematic issues.  
 
The third category of study is a diagnostic report on a sector or 
thematic area that can cover single or multi-country studies, with 
the latter allowing comparative policy analysis. This study 
category will give priority to themes and/or sectors aligned with 
ADB’s Strategy 2030.a New and emerging topics such as 
technological and digital change will also be considered in a 
forward-looking manner. 
 
Output 2 will support development and enhancement of DMC 
officials’ capacity in employing diagnostic approaches and tools 
to conduct economic and policy analysis. The output will include 
training workshops to help create awareness and improve the 
capacity of DMC officials and think tanks involved in the 
preparation of national, sector, and thematic development plans 
and policies. It will also produce knowledge products on the 
application of the analytical tools that can be used to undertake 
policy analysis.  
Indicative implementation  ADB will administer subproject 1. EREA will be directly 
arrangements  responsible for TA subproject administration and supervision, 
management of consultants, procurement, and accomplishment 
of outputs. The TA subproject proposal(s) will be submitted for 
approval to the ERCD chief economist and director general, 
following the business process for knowledge and support TA 
cluster processing.b 
Implementation schedule  August 2021–July 2024
